title: Quiz 1: Infection Prevention Basics
description: Test your knowledge on the chain of infection, standard precautions, and hand washing techniques.

questions.question: What is the single most effective method of preventing or decreasing the transfer of micro-organisms in a health facility?
questions.explanation: Washing hands before and after contact with each patient is cited as the single most effective method of preventing/decreasing transfer of micro-organisms.
questions.hint: It involves soap, water, and friction.

questions.question: In the disease transmission cycle, infectious agents leave the reservoir through a place of exit and enter a susceptible host through a ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The cycle moves from reservoir -> exit -> mode of transmission -> place of entry -> susceptible host.
questions.hint: Where the pathogen gets into the new host.

questions.question: Which of the following are considered 'Standard Precautions'? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Standard precautions include hand washing, PPE use, and safe sharps disposal. Needles should never be recapped by hand, and disposable gloves are never sterilized/reused.
questions.hint: Think about practices applied to ALL patients regardless of diagnosis.

questions.question: Match the type of hand washing with its description:

richContent.content:
MethodUse Case
1. RoutineSoap and running water
2. AntisepticAntimicrobial soap + water
3. Alcohol RubWhen hands not visibly soiled
4. Surgical ScrubBefore operative procedures

pairs.right: Kills/inhibits resident organisms; for high risk
Used when water unavailable; hands not soiled
Prevents growth of organisms for a period of time

questions.explanation: Routine uses plain soap; Antiseptic uses antimicrobial agents for invasive procedures; Alcohol rub is for unsoiled hands; Surgical scrub provides prolonged inhibition.
questions.hint: Match the intensity of the wash with the risk level.

questions.question: Alcohol-based hand rubs are effective even when hands are visibly soiled with blood or organic material.
questions.explanation: Alcohol hand rub can be used when hand washing is not possible ONLY as long as hands are not visibly soiled with dirt, blood, or other organic material.
questions.hint: Think about the physical removal of dirt.

questions.question: Which antiseptic is best recommended for use in the genital area, vagina, and cervix?
questions.explanation: Iodophors are relatively non-irritating and non-toxic, making them the best choice for mucous membranes. Pure iodine and high-concentration alcohol are too irritating.
questions.hint: It is less irritating than pure iodine.

questions.question: What is the term for hospital-acquired infections?
questions.explanation: Hospital acquired infections are known as nosocomial infections.

questions.question: Order the steps of the Disease Transmission Cycle:
questions.explanation: Agents survive in a Reservoir -> Leave via Exit -> Travel via Transmission -> Enter via Entry -> Into Susceptible Host.
questions.hint: Start with where the germ lives.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered 'Normal Flora'?

options.text: Micro-organisms not normally found in the body
Micro-organisms normally present on skin and tracts

questions.explanation: Normal flora are micro-organisms normally present on people's skin, respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

questions.question: Standard precautions should only be applied to patients confirmed to have infectious diseases like HIV or Hepatitis B.
questions.explanation: Standard precautions apply to EVERY patient regardless of their presumed infection status because you cannot always tell who is infected.
